title: Types of Sampling: Turn the Lights on
question_text: A town committee is thinking about investing $\$200,000$ for lighting the baseball fields. The first selectman of the town wants to survey $500\text{ citizens}$ of the town to see what they think. Which of the following will produce a simple random sample?

choices.text: Surveying every fourth citizen who walks by the town hall.
Randomly selecting $500\text{ citizens}$ from the local phone directory.
Using the latest census data from the town, numbering the citizens, and using a random number generator to select $500\text{ citizens}$.

Separate by age groups using the latest census data from the community. The age groups would be $18-30$, $31-45$, $46-65$, and $65$ and over. Randomly select two of the age groups and randomly survey $250$ citizens from those two age groups.

Separate by age groups using the latest census data from the community. The age groups would be 18−30, 31−45, 46−65, and 65 and over. Randomly select 125 citizens ages 18−30, 125 citizens ages 31−45, 125 citizens ages 46−65, and 125 citizens ages 65 and over.

solution:
A simple random sample is a sample in which every group of size n individuals has an equal chance to be chosen. In this case, we are looking for the option in which in every possible sample of size 500 has an equal chance of being chosen.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect as this an example of systematic sampling.

Choice 'B' is incorrect as not every possible sample of 500 citizens
have an equal chance of being selected since some citizens do not have a phone or their phone number is unlisted.

Choice 'D' is incorrect as not every possible sample of 500 citizens have an equal chance of being selected. In this design, we are limited to 250
citizens from two age brackets. If this was a simple random sample, we should be able to get a sample of, say, 500 citizens
in the age range of 31−45
.

Choice 'E' is incorrect as this is an example of a stratified random sample. In this design, we are limited to 125 citizens
from each age bracket. If this was a simple random sample, we should be able to get a sample of say 500
citizens in the age range of 31−45
.
